awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of RNA-directed activation of a Cas9 nuclease competent for DNA interrogation.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how a complex of an RNA and protein, named CRISPR-Cas9, works as a molecular scissor to change an organism's DNA. CRISPR-Cas9 is natively used by lower organisms such as bacteria to defend against viral infections. The CRISPR-Cas9 system is being adapted as a powerful tool for manipulating genomes of many organisms in a 'by-design and on-demand' fashion. On the horizon are innovations that use CRISPR-Cas9 to produce drought-resistant crops; to combat mosquito transmitted diseases such as malaria; and to cure human illness by fixing an individual's faulty DNA. While studies on CRISPR-Cas9 have advanced rapidly and are poised to revolutionize many fields in biology, details on its mechanism of action remain to be elucidated. This project will fill this knowledge gap by identifying the mechanisms by which RNA molecules convert Cas9's molecular structure into a form suitable for selecting DNA targets. Beyond advancing scientific understanding and methodologies, the project will explore collaborations with biotech companies that may yield new technological applications and promote economic developments. It also includes research training for students at all levels and curriculum innovations such as 'virtual reality' (VR) demonstrations of the Cas9-RNA complex, thus contributing to the development of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) workforce.

The overall objective of the project is to elucidate the roles of specific domains of Cas9 and guide RNA in initiating and directing a cascade of conformational changes towards the state ready for DNA interrogation. The proposed work will leverage on the expertise of the PI in the functional and structural (X-ray crystallography) characterization of protein-nucleic acid complexes; and that of the Co-PI in site directed spin labeling studies of nucleic acids and protein-nucleic acid complexes. Experiments will focus on Streptococcus pyogenes Cas9, the workhorse in genome engineering, and test an overarching hypothesis that the interactions of the bridge-helix of Cas9 with specific RNA elements, initiate and induce Cas9 domain rearrangements to assemble a DNA-interrogative protein-RNA complex. Specific Aims are: Dissect the role of the bridge helix in initiating conformational changes in Cas9 (Aim 1); Identify the protein and RNA elements that displaces the nuclease lobe (Aim 2) and a helical domain (HD-III, Aim 3) in response to the bridge-helix conformational change. The results from the three aims will identify the sequential steps in the conformational cascade and will be widely applicable to similar CRISPR-Cas systems.

por.por_cntn:
This is a collaborative project with Dr. Rakhi Rajan (MCB-1716423). The project aims to understand RNA-induced conformational changes that convert apo-Cas9 to a competent enzyme with specific DNA targeting ability. Cas9 is a protein belonging to the bacterial immune response system, CRISPR-Cas [Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR) − CRISPR associated (Cas)], and has been adapted as a powerful genome editing tool. Even though studies have clearly established the necessity of RNA-mediated protein conformational changes in the function of multiple Cas9 orthologs, how the protein and RNA elements bring about the cascade of conformational changes that define target specificity is not yet fully understood. Our over-arching hypothesis is that an Arg-rich bridge-helix (BH) of Cas9 undergoes a loop-to-helix transition upon single-guide RNA (sgRNA) binding; initiating and inducing Cas9 domain rearrangements to produce the effector complex competent in targeting DNA. Using Streptococcus pyogenes (Spy) Cas9 as the model, we are testing this hypothesis through functionally and structurally characterizing designed Cas9 variants using a combination of biochemical, biophysical, and cell-based assays. This collaborative project was overall led by Dr. Rakhi Rajan at the University of Oklahoma. My lab?s major roles were to conduct spin-labeling/EPR measurements to assess SpyCas9 conformational changes and to develop quantitative models for analyzing enzyme kinetic data. As of the date of this report, this grant has supported work reported in five published and submitted manuscripts, with one additional manuscript in preparation. The work also produced one US patent that has been granted. Major scientific developments and findings include:

 (1) Developing new venues to engineering CRISPR-Cas proteins to enhance specificity. Work on SpyCas9 BH has yielded a high-fidelity variant, SpyCas92Pro. Spin-labeling/EPR studies, in conjunction with mutagenesis and enzyme kinetics data, reveal that increasing heterogeneity in BH conformation in sgRNA-bound SpyCas92Pro is responsible for enhancing substrate discrimination. The work demonstrates that modulating the integrity of BH, which is conserved across the Cas9 and Cas12a family, is a viable means to generate high-fidelity CRISPR variants. This is further supported by parallel work demonstrating enhancing specificity with a BH variants in FnoCas12a. Beyond the BH variants, a SpyCas9H982A variant that greatly reduces undesired non-specific gRNA-free DNA cleavage has also been developed.

(2) Developing a parallel-sequential kinetic model for analyzing coordinated actions of the Cas9 nucleases. From our kinetics studies, we have established the use of the parallel-sequential kinetic model with the supper-coiled DNA substrates to dissect cleavage rate constants for Cas9 substrate cleavage. The information revealed complex behaviors in the coordination between the two nuclease domains in Cas9 (i.e., HNH cleaving the target strand and RuvC cleaving the non-target strand), which differ depending on protein mutation (e.g., 2Pro within BH) and DNA target alteration (e.g., matched vs. mismatched). The studies advance our fundamental understanding of Cas9 reaction mechanism, as well as generate new possibility for engineering better Cas9 variants.

(3) Continuing developments of site-directed spin-labeling methods for studying protein-nucleic acids complex. In particular, work on SpyCas92Pro represents the first report of CRISPR protein conformational changes revealed by spin-labeling/EPR. It established a number of methods for further investigating CRISPR as well as other protein-nucleic acid complexes.

 The Intellectual Merit of the work manifested as: (i) advancing mechanistic understanding on target discrimination of Cas9 to guide development of CRISPR variants with enhanced fidelity; (ii) advancing site-directly spin-labeling methodology for studying nucleic acids and protein-nucleic acid complexes such as CRISPR-Cas9.

The Broader Impacts of the work manifested as: (i) developing high-fidelity CRISPR-Cas9 and Cas12a variants that benefit genome engineering applications; and (ii) advancing methodology and fundamental understanding on CRISPR (e.g., the parallel-sequential kinetic model; spin-labeling work on Cas9 complexes) that benefit the broader scientific community. The grant also supported service to the broader scientific community through the PI?s work within the Internal EPR Society. The grant supported work on STEM work force development by training students with diverse background, including minorities and pre-college students.
